App description: Drunkn Bar Fight is a simple, immersive, silly, rowdy game. Now with 2 player Co-op! Take turns throwing bottles, darts, chairs, tip jars or anything else you can get your hands on at opponents. Or use those same items to smash the other patrons to the floor and then toss them through plate glass window. Enjoy performing socially unacceptable behavior without the resulting obligatory visits to the hospital, jail and courts. The only limits to the mayhem is your imagination and your moral decency.

Cian28Jul 3 at 11:47 PM
A Sidequest-type game.

The game is fun for a few minutes, but only if you are new to VR. As a long time VR gamer, this game unfortunately doesnt live up to my expectations, and is frankly overpriced . The physics are Jank, the co-op is unstable, and there really isnt a lot of motivation to play.

On the up side, this game has massive potential to be a top, must-have game. Heres what I would recommend changing in order to get it there:

1- Add a competitive mode, where friends can fight each-other

2- Utilize a better physics engine, one that allows objects to actually collide, instead of pseudo-colliding. The objects in this game like to phase through things a lot.

3- Create an easy way to track points during gameplay, instead of just at the end of the session.

4- Increase the texture quality.

No Cross Buy/Cross Play

I have a Rift CV1 and recently bought a Quest, hoping to play some multiplayer games with my son in VR. I had already bought this game for my rift, and bought it a second time on my quest with a second account.

Then I find out this is one of a few games that does not support cross play between rift and quest.

OK, I thought, no biggie. Ill just sign in to my quest account on my laptop and use the Oculus Link cable to play it like a Rift, that way we are both using rifts so we can play together.

Nope.

The devs decided to also not make this game cross buy, meaning even though I purchased this game on my quest, and Im using that account on my pc, I would have to purchase the exact same game for a third time if I wanted to play it with my son.

This game isnt worth the price they charge for one copy, much less buying it on every platform. The devs are money hungry and I will keep fighting with Oculus to get a refund for at least one purchase.

Good For What I Paid

For starters, I got this game at a discounted price and I used the starter $5 store credit - bringing the price down to $4.74. I believe that this game should be around $5 as $15 is pretty steep considering the lack of content.

Pros:
- Funny as hell
- Lots of different objects and weapons to fight with
- Customizable character
- Reminds me of POSTAL 2
- 4 different levels to choose from

Cons:
- $15 regular price is too much for the amount of content
- Physics can be wonky at times
- Glitchy, sometimes my character's hands don't work when attempting to grab things
- Repeating levels over and over is a necessity to unlock more items/customizations

Overall a fun game, I just wish there was more content.

Physically satisfying, visually awful

This game is a good chunk of fun and a great experience to share. The physics are good for the most part, enough to be satisfying when you hit someone. There is some collision issues with this game. Some objects break when you touch them before you grab them, detection is flaky, and some objects don't collide with the enemies.

Although it's a nice game, it's possibly one of the visually horrendous games I've played on the Quest. It's sightly akin to a unity asset flip, and that doesn't make me feel like I got my money's worth. A distinctive art style can make a world of difference, but this looks like they took a tech demo beta and called it quits.

Get this game on sale if you can, I'd suggest below $8...

ShadowMannSep 21, 2019 at 9:26 PM
Stripped down for Quest, but still fun

I have both an Oculus Rift S and a Quest. The idea was to go portable with the apps I love on the Rift S and this is my most played game. It's cool, silly and loads of fun to play. On the Rift S, the bar is full of people, and there are baseball bats to fight with, lots more bottles to smash (and drink), fire extinguishers you can fight with, and the fighting is more intense. For the Quest, there are only three people in the bar at any given time, and the characters familiar in the Rift S version are in the Quest version, but the Quest version has a couple of different characters not in the Rift S version. It isn't as realistic as the PCVR version. People don't just come running into a bar to fight you who have never interacted with you.

Overall, it is well worth the $14+ they want for the game if you own a Quest. If you have played this game on a tethered PCVR, you will notice that it is stripped down. Still giving it 4 stars. Too much compromise, but this is not the Dev's fault.

Developer ResponseSep 12, 2019 at 10:02 PM

DAX_Qc, Thanks for giving us a shot! There is an option on the in game cell phone to select which button is used for grab. You can choose "grab button" or "Trigger". We defaulted to trigger because in DBF you throw a lot of objects and if you have larger hands, using the grab button moves one of the last fingers holding the controller off the device at the exact time you release the virtual object. Thank you for alerting us, we obviously need to make a notification letting people know of this option. This is why we really appreciate you taking the time to leave a review. Before you give up on the game, can you please try something if you haven't already. What I am about to ask you won't improve the graphics, the physics or the options but I hope it will help you understand why folks like the game. Setup a very large Guardian in a very open space. Then, play DBF without using snapturn or using the joysticks to move. Do everything with your body and not with the controller. Move around the space freely dodging, punching, blocking, smashing. I hope this helps you enjoy the game. Thanks for the feedback.
